text.title: part7_Augusten Burroughs on addiction, writing, his family and his new book

p: But it's also just the prose; I just find it beautiful, the simplicity of it. It's just very beautiful.

p.hi: DS: In the Vanity Fair article Teresa said that she had come down to New York to visit you with her kids--
DS: And that you were saying that you want to marry her, how great she is, what a kind person she is…

p: AB: Right before Running with Scissors was published, I was thinking about her, and I thought, "She is going to love this book.” I remember feeling really excited because I thought, "She is going to be blown away." That period of growing up together was a very pivotal and central aspect to both of our lives, hers and mine, and we shared it together. And I thought, “Man, when she reads this she is”--

p.hi: DS: She's really going to be there with you.

p: AB: Yes. She's going to be like, "Oh, my God, I can't believe you remembered this. I had forgotten about that. Oh, my God--" I thought, she's gonna be so blown away that I remembered so much and brought it all back; I felt like I was giving her our childhood again. So when the lawsuit occurred, it took me by absolute surprise. To find out she was involved in it, I was shocked, and then I was disgusted. I was just blankly disgusted, because it reeked to me of just greed. It had, you know--

p.hi: DS: Do you think that's what it was, the motivation?

p: AB: I've learned never to try to put a word on them. I don't know what the fuck it was about. Did I say one thing in there that really hurt her? I didn't mean to, but obviously, I guess I did, you know? Was it about the money--did they think they could get a lot of money? I'll never know the answer to that, and I don't even want to know, now.

It's unfortunate, it's unfortunate, but I'm not at all sorry that I wrote it. And you know, the suit settled-- it settled in my favor. I didn't change a word of the memoir, not one word of it. It's still a memoir, it's marketed as a memoir, they've agreed one hundred percent that it is a memoir. You know, the only thing I--

p.hi: DS: They got what they wanted apparently from settling with Sony?

p: AB: Yeah, right. There you go, exactly I mean, if it was not about money, and it was about, you know--

AB: Yeah. Then they didn't do a very good job of showing that. I'm just really glad that it's over, and I know I'm not vindicated. A lot of people are still like, how did that resolve? I feel vindicated, because of the way that it settled. They couldn't have done anything else. They never could have won. We had such an incredibly strong case. I mean, the lawyers worked like hell and got witnesses, and I had my journals--I mean, it's--there were a lot of other people around back then, you know?
